_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan Executive Summary
Inland Chemical Service Inc
Condon, Oregon

1.	Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
Our facilityA¿s primary activities include support services for crop production. We have anhydrous ammonia stored in one 18,000 gallon aboveground ASME tank, at our facility in Condon, Oregon. The maximum amount stored at our facility is 15,300 gallons (83,948 lbs).

2.	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response
Inland Chemical Service is committed to the safety of our employees, the public and the environment. This commitment is an inherent part of our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers process areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance and employee training at our facility. It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. We coordinate our response efforts with Gilliam County Emergency Services and the Condon Fire Department.

3.	Accidental Release Prevention program
Our facility has taken the necessary steps to comply with the requirements set forth in 40 CFR, Part 68. The following sections briefly describe the elements of our accidental release prevention program.

a.	Process Safety Information
Inland Chemical Service maintains a detailed record of safety information describing the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with the processes at our facility.

b.	Process Hazard Analysis
We conduct periodic reviews to ensure the hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled effectively. Findings from our Hazard Analysis reviews are addressed in a timely manner.

c.	Operating Procedures
We maintain written operating procedures to ensure that activities within our covered processes are conducted safely. Operating procedures are reviewed periodically and updated as needed.

d.	Training
Inland Chemical Service uses a comprehensive training program

to ensure employees involved in our processes are competent in the operation and maintenance of our facilities. Employees receive annual training on the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia. Employees also receive training if any updates or modifications are made to our facility that would affect operations or maintenance.

e.	Mechanical Integrity
Documented monthly facility inspections are conducted by trained and qualified employees. These inspections include the storage container and all related equipment. Maintenance is performed as needed and documented. 

f.	Program Compliance Audits
Periodic compliance audits are performed to ensure our program meets the requirements of 40 CFR, Part 68. Audits include all components of our Risk Management Program. Inland Chemical Service contracts with a third-party safety consultant to perform annual safety inspections and program compliance audits.

4.	Five-year Accident History
Due to our stringent release prevention policies, no accidental releases have occurred at this facility in the last five years.

5.	Emergency Response Plan
Inland Chemical Service maintains a written Emergency Action Plan for our facility. The plan addresses emergency response issues including first aid, medical treatment and evacuation procedures. Information and procedures for contacting local response agencies (fire department, LEPC) are included in this plan.

6.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Inland Chemical Service will continue to provide training as needed to employees involved in our covered processes. We will conduct monthly facility inspections to ensure our equipment and processes are safe. Deficiencies identified during audits and reviews will be addressed in a timely manner.
